subject: RE: [junit] Standalone or "requires environment" information
msgSnippet: ... I prefer the idea of well designed code that makes it easy to substitute the /environment/ for a MockObject  instead.  This, IMHO, is
messageBody:
> Differentiating between completely standalone tests (eg StingUtility
> classes) or requires a test environment (eg database, file structure)
> would be terrific, especially with the Ant junit batchtest structure,
> where Ant works its way through the code and finds Tester classes to
> run. It doesn't have any way of knowing the environment that it's
> running in, or the environment that the test needs.

I prefer the idea of well designed code that makes it easy to substitute
the /environment/ for a MockObject <www.mockobjects.com> instead. This,
IMHO, is the true nature of *unit* tests. What you want to know is that
your code responds to the environment in the expected way.

Thus you create mock objets for a faulty database: method call throws
exception; a normal db call: the method returns a valid response; etc.

This gives you complete control over the responses you expect from the
environment, and allow you to test your code under expected conditions.
It also means that your unit test suite will be a lot faster.

There is also a place for functional or acceptance tests. These tests,
like integrations tests, would be used to test that the different
components work as expected when put together. If these tests take
longer to run, you could schedule them to run once every evening, or
once a week over the weekend, while running the quicker performing unit
tests every time you think of checking some code into Source/Version
control.
